DOC.HEAD: Lebanese TV, Newspapers Release Christmas Messages To Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers, radio and television stations today released morale-boosting messages to eight Americans held hostage in Lebanon, including two marking a fifth Christimas in captivity. But there was no way to ascertain whether Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland, kidnapped in 1985, or any of the other American captives who are believed held by Shiite Moslem extremists were allowed to hear or read the messages. ``I can hardly believe that your fifth Christmas season in captivity is approaching,'' said Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, in a letter written in advance to coincide with Christmas. ``Despite having no valid reason for believing that you might celebrate this season as a free man, my faith prompts me to pray very hard for a Christmas miracle,'' she wrote. The English text of her letter was published by the newspaper An-Nahar along with an Arabic translation. The conservative Al-Anwar, the pro-Syrian Ash-Sharq and the Moslem Al-Liwa published the Arabic translation of the letter, and radio and television stations broadcast the message in English. ``We are counting on you to hold yourself together physically, spiritually and emotionally until your day of freedom comes,'' Mrs. Say wrote to Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. ``Until then, stay strong and know that neither you nor those held with you are alone or forgotten. Your daughters are as always, well and beautiful.'' Anderson has two daughters, Gabrielle, 13, and Sulome, 4. The younger daughter was born three months after he was kidnapped on March 16, 1985. Anderson, 42, of Lorain, Ohio, is the longest-held of the 18 Western captives in Lebanon. He and Sutherland, 58, of Fort Collins, Colo., are held by Islamic Jihad, or Holy War, an extremist group seeking the release of 15 comrades jailed in Kuwait on terrorist charges. Sutherland, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, was kidnapped June 9, 1985. One newspaper, the leftist As-Safir, published a paid advertisement in Arabic and English carrying the message to Sutherland. It was signed by his wife, Jean, his daughters Ann, Simone, Kit, and Joan and the Murray and Sutherland families. ``May this find you and bring all the gifts we have of love, hope, comfort, and spirit,'' the letter said. ``We wait for you _ we exist, we do not live without you.'' The newspapers also published a letter from the Journalists Committee to Free Terry Anderson that was addressed to all eight Americans. The six others are Frank Reed, Joseph Cicippio, Edward Austin Tracy, Alann Steen, Jesse Turner and Robert Polhill. ``We had hoped and prayed that this Christmas would be different from the others and we'd see you all home,'' said the letter signed by Bill Foley and Cary Vaughan for the committee. It concluded: ``Someday, someway, you will come home.'' The other foreign hostages in Lebanon include four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman.
